dialogue.text: Alright, so today we're talking about something that I think a lot of restaurant operators don't fully understand. Delivery revenue.
Yeah, and specifically how to protect it. Because there's actually a lot of money that just... leaks out of the system.
Exactly. We're going to break down how delivery actually works, where those leaks happen, and most importantly, how to fix them.
So let's start with the basics. How do restaurants make money?
Well, there's really three channels, right? Dine-in, takeout, and delivery.
Right. And with dine-in, you see the customer. You control the whole experience.
Takeout is similar. They walk in, grab their food, leave. Pretty straightforward.
But delivery... [sighs] that's where things get complicated.
Because your food goes to someone you've never met. And once it leaves your kitchen, you have no idea what happens next.
Let me paint the picture here. The restaurant makes the food. That's their job, they're great at it.
But then the platform takes over. DoorDash, Uber Eats, Grubhub...
They own the customer relationship. They handle the payment. They do the delivery.
And here's the thing that really gets me. When something goes wrong?
The customer complains to the platform, not the restaurant.
Exactly! You have zero direct recourse. None.
Okay, this next one is kind of scary. You ready?
[laughs] You're being dramatic. But go ahead.
Picture this. Inside the store, everything looks great. Busy kitchen, staff working, orders flowing.
Okay...
But on the delivery app? The store shows as unavailable. Completely invisible.
Oh wow. So customers literally can't see them.
Right! And the worst part? Nobody inside the restaurant even knows it's happening.
That's revenue that never even gets a chance to happen. That's terrifying actually.
